content.html:
Part of the coding style in Gazebo is to open curly braces in a new line as follows:

  if (condition)
  {
    // content with 2 space indentation
  }

  for (condition)
  {
    // content with 2 space indentation
  }

content.raw:
I'm not sure why yet, but this branch doesn't build for me, with the following error. `default` builds though.

~~~
librobocup3dsPlugin.so.0.1.0: undefined reference to `gazebo::event::Events::worldUpdateBegin'
librobocup3dsPlugin.so.0.1.0: undefined reference to `gazebo::event::Connection::Connection(gazebo::event::Event*, int)'
librobocup3dsPlugin.so.0.1.0: undefined reference to `gazebo::event::Connection::~Connection()'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
~~~
content.html:
I'm not sure why yet, but this branch doesn't build for me, with the following error. default builds though.

librobocup3dsPlugin.so.0.1.0: undefined reference to `gazebo::event::Events::worldUpdateBegin'
librobocup3dsPlugin.so.0.1.0: undefined reference to `gazebo::event::Connection::Connection(gazebo::event::Event*, int)'
librobocup3dsPlugin.so.0.1.0: undefined reference to `gazebo::event::Connection::~Connection()'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status

content.raw:
I just saw that you used both `///` and `//` for "Documentation inherited" and I got curious to learn which is the correct one. 

It turns out `//` is the correct one as explained [here](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/122/changes-to-doxygen-comments-and-formatting/diff#comment-44450), even though we have quite a few `/// Documentation inherited` in Gazebo still.
content.html:
I just saw that you used both /// and // for "Documentation inherited" and I got curious to learn which is the correct one.

It turns out // is the correct one as explained here, even though we have quite a few /// Documentation inherited in Gazebo still.

content.raw:
We usually organize the headers like this:

1. public functions

1. protected functions

1. private functions

1. public variables

1. protected variables

1. private variables
content.html:
We usually organize the headers like this:

  1. public functions

  2. protected functions

  3. private functions

  4. public variables

  5. protected variables

  6. private variables

content.html: Also be careful with the 2-space indentation, the doxygen should be aligned with the rest.

content.raw:
Can we choose one pattern to name these variables? How about they all start with caps and have no `_` in between words? Such as `GoalKickRight`. Maybe they can even be exactly the same as the state name, what do you think?

* Note that `FreeKickRight` -> `kick_kick_right` is mistaken right now
content.html:
Can we choose one pattern to name these variables? How about they all start with caps and have no _ in between words? Such as GoalKickRight. Maybe they can even be exactly the same as the state name, what do you think?

  • Note that FreeKickRight -> kick_kick_right is mistaken right now

content.raw: We shouldn't use raw pointers. Use smart pointers instead. I guess in this case a std::shared_ptr is a better option.

content.raw: You don't need to #include these files here, I believe it's OK to do a forward declaration to speed up compilation. We usually follow the rule that each file should declare everything that needs. In this case, `GameState.cc` will have all these `#include`.
content.html: You don't need to #include these files here, I believe it's OK to do a forward declaration to speed up compilation. We usually follow the rule that each file should declare everything that needs. In this case, GameState.cc will have all these #include.
